[h1]Toem: A Cozy Game Centered around Photography-Related Quests[/h1]

[h2][u]Overview[/u][/h2]
I‚Äôm a sucker for the task based ‚Äúcozy‚Äù genre like [i]A Short Hike[/i]. Toem probably set the bar for this genre as my new favorite. It does everything right with solid game design choices and is just overall a pleasant experience that was perfect for unwinding at the end of the day.

[h2][u]Story[/u][/h2]
While I am a fan of the ‚ÄúCozy‚Äù games, I desperately need some kind of drive to keep playing. Open-ended cozy games without a clear story to keep you moving and questing just feel aimless to me and I lose interest. Thankfully, Toem has no such problems and has a clear goal established from the very beginning. You‚Äôre on an adventure to tour a mystical sight, but it‚Äôs at the top of a mountain several towns away. Thus to fund this trip, you do quests for people to earn bus fare. You then take the bus to the next town and do more quests to earn more bus fare. Repeat until you make it to the final destination! It‚Äôs a simple premise and full of enough diverse locations, tasks, puzzles and cast of characters to keep it from getting stale. As a bonus, there was even a free DLC and a short vacation bonus story to play as an epilogue after you finish the base game.

[h2][u]Presentation[/u][/h2]
This game oozes style with its unique black and white presentation and music you can turn your brain off and hum along to. There are plenty of different locations to explore and each does a very good job capturing a different feeling. Each new biome has its own set of animals to find and snap pictures of, allowing the game to double as a collectathon ‚Äì gotta snap them all! There is some customization where you can dress the main character up. Some of the dress up is required for the quests, but there‚Äôs plenty of optional clothes and accessories as well.

[h2][u]Gameplay[/u][/h2]
The game is highly integrated with the story ‚Äì the game is essentially interacting with the world around you which feels very alive. As you take off from the bus stop you can ask to see how many stamps you require to go to the next area. Then off you go to talk with NPCs. As you help them out and complete tasks they‚Äôll reward you with stamps and sometimes accessories/clothes or new gadgets or ways to progress through the area. 

The game is appealing to both completionists and casuals in its game design approach. You do not have to help every single NPC as there are far more tasks/stamps available than are required to proceed to the next area. But the number isn‚Äôt so overwhelming that you‚Äôd want to skip. Its really fun to try to 100% every area and do everything you possibly can. 

As you talk to NPCs your card will get updated with tasks for them. Sometimes you may be surprised and help them before you even realize it was a task. Other times it can be more complex or a bit harder to interpret what is meant to be done. But for the most part, the quests seemed to be at an engaging enough level to keep me interested but not so difficult that I ever wanted to skip any. At worst, there were a few times I felt kind of lost trying to hunt down very specific animals which were intended to be difficult to find in the first place. 

I played this game in the evenings before bed and it was a very relaxing experience and I never felt frustrated but wasn‚Äôt complete brain-off either.

[h2][u]Summary[/u][/h2]
Overall, Toem was such a delightful experience that I immediately had to send it to several of my friends. It‚Äôs cute, charming, and most importantly for a game‚Äîfun! It cured my life long depression even if only for a temporary 4 to 5 hours. But what a time that was. Honestly, I prefer shorter games as I am more likely to actually complete them. I think it was just the right length and didn‚Äôt ever feel close to overstaying its welcome. Super looking forward to the sequel.

The game centers around an unnamed, lightly triangle-shaped and uncannily Moomin-resembling character, who is sent onto a grand, coming-of-age adventure by their photographer enthusiast grandmother (or ‚ÄúNana‚Äù, as the game prefers to call her) to witness the legendary phenomenon at the peak of Kiiruberg mountain, the titular ‚ÄúTOEM‚Äù.

[h1]Review[/h1]
I learned of TOEM very late (I believe it was only early this year) and man is it better late than ever. All of the positive reception TOEM has received is well-deserved. The game takes its photography mechanics, and even stretches the defined bounds of photo-taking a little, to deliver a real masterclass in lively and endearing world design, with a really beautiful, relaxing soundtrack. Additional tracks may be unlocked as puzzle rewards, to either play at random or be chosen at will by opening the menu of the game‚Äôs in-world music device, the ‚ÄúHikelady‚Äù (yes, a silly play on the Sony ‚ÄúWalkman‚Äù, which did make me chuckle more than it should‚Äôve when it clicked). All locations are based around a ‚Äúcommunity stamp collection‚Äù, help the local community of any given location you‚Äôre in and they will reward you for your efforts with stamps. Collect enough stamps, and your bus fare to the next location is covered for free, by virtue of you being such a good sport to multiple communities throughout the game‚Äôs runtime. It‚Äôs a fantastic premise, and an honest-to-god utopian idea.

TOEM‚Äôs strength lies chiefly in the fact it rarely takes itself particularly seriously. It‚Äôs a photography game, sure, but you won‚Äôt be doing any hardcore photography, instead you‚Äôll be capturing silly pictures of silly and sometimes mysterious things to complete your collection book of local fauna or to help out the local townsfolk with finding things they‚Äôve lost, or even taking photographs of weird space anomalies to put a few magicked items to the state they ought to be in. No puzzles are particularly hard, but they will make you think and explore and pay attention to all of your surroundings in a beautiful way, that helps you appreciate everything around you, which is precisely what photography should achieve anyway, so the game captures the spirit of the premise perfectly there, even if in a roundabout way.

As for flaws? You might stumble upon the rare obscurely phrased puzzle, or even a puzzle that seems like it could mean multiple things: I, for instance, found myself particularly irked by one or two puzzles in ‚ÄúLogcity‚Äù, the game‚Äôs third big area. A lot of this can be forgiven, as it was literally two quests of like a hundred, and all of them are short enough throughout the game‚Äôs runtime to not outstay their welcome or sully your experience, and some handy guides are always there, made by a few helpful users here on Steam for example, which will help you out if you find yourself in the rare pickle. I have to fess up here, however, to the fact that I beat TOEM‚Äôs entire 6-7 hour campaign in one-sitting, so with healthier breaks and a more leisurely pace you‚Äôre likely to not run into these possibly fatigue-bolstered frustrations.

Lastly, even though the game doesn‚Äôt take itself too seriously, I would‚Äôve loved some sharpness and depth of field options to really bring out certain objects in the foreground from the background in a more elegant way, which only goes double for a monochrome, low contrast world such as this one. The game does give you a few frames/stickers and filters to play around with, but they‚Äôre fairly primitive and go mostly unused in the puzzles, which is a shame. Also, for some reason, that I presume to be a stylistic choice, the characters and fauna in TOEM (basically anything that is living or moves in any significant way) is lower quality than the still life, which I find a little strange. I often found myself zooming onto characters in the world and seeing the pristine background behind them, while the light texturing and some lines seemed awkwardly blurry. Your eyes adjust rather swiftly to this weird phenomenon, but still, I can‚Äôt say it was a choice I particularly welcomed for a photography game.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
If you‚Äôve never played and/or heard of TOEM, do me a favor and play it! Have you already played TOEM and have kids in your family, or even have some of your own? Show them TOEM. Despite its lack of color, the game‚Äôs general shapes, aesthetics, locales, as well as its humorous and adventurous vibes put me strongly in mind of Hilda by Luke Pearson, and I‚Äôd personally struggle to find higher praise for another whimsical, family-friendly piece of art than that.

One of those games that wears its appeal on its sleeve pretty clearly without there being a ton to really surprise you about how it succeeds at what it does. That's not to say that TOEM is a bad game at all however, quite the opposite, bringing forth a profoundly comforting experience that does just enough as to not feel totally mindless. The artstyle in particular stands out to me when considering the sort of game this is, pairing the goal of taking a lot of pictures of everything with a purely monochromatic palette, bringing more attention to noting all the weird little unexpected movements of your surroundings or even just, vaguely interesting shapes, which I found got me feeling even more intimately aware of the world.

This is made even more exciting and satisfying by the way a lot of the little jobs you get are laid out, being spread all across the different locations and often getting you to backtrack to take some pictures of cool things. However, the game ends up indirectly teaching you as a result to be paying especially close attention to anything that could strike you as even vaguely interesting. I feel like TOEM ends up striking this really interesting balance where you're taking pictures due to knowing that they'll probably be relevant later, yet it feels like you're just taking pictures for the intrinsic reward of getting to have your little character experience the world even moreso. It's a weird dynamic that I haven't really seen performed quite so well, and is a big part of why I think there's some seriously impressive and elegant design work that goes into this, giving that core gameplay some real teeth just through how magical the act of taking a photo ends up becoming.

The only real complaint I have here is that I do feel like some of the atmosphere of taking a journey further away from home gets lost due to the ease of backtracking. There are some moments of the game that really frame what you're doing as this grandiose, but slightly intimidating circumstance that constantly puts you into increasingly alienating situations as you're leaving that comfort of home, but they end up clashing a bit with the fact that home is just a bus stop away. I understand that for a game like this, it might've been thought of as too much to make the player commit to travelling to their next big location each time, but I also think that even making it that full fast travel being unlocked at the end of the game as a way to clean up anything you missed could be a good compromise as to lead to something a little more emotionally resonant, even if what's here now is still beautiful. Sometimes a short, 3 hour game packed with more charm than anything else is good for the soul, sometimes you've just gotta play something that makes you feel like you're cozily wrapped up in a blanket, and this fill that niche wonderfully.

A few things to know right off the bat. Toem isn't a long game. I was able to 100% it in under 10 hours (including Basto), so don't go into this expecting a long experience. Additionally, there isn't a lot of replay value. Once you've finished everything, that's it. You can of course go back and enjoy the cute world the game offers, taking additional photos to add to your album, but there isn't any actual content worth replaying.

All of that being said, this is an amazing little game. It's fun, lighthearted, and adorable. The mechanics are fun, the puzzles clever, and the world is just plain enjoyable to explore and interact with. At no point did I find any facet of the game to be dull or boring, no activity was tedious. Everything was the perfect length to not wear out its welcome. For the full $20 price tag, I think this is worth it for a day's entertainment. Even better if it's discounted.

A few quirks and notes to be mindful of:
- Some of the quests can't be completed until you visit other areas. Don't get stuck in one area trying to complete everything because you probably can't.
- There were a very few instances where it wasn't clear what you were supposed to do. Everything revolves around your camera, so just keep trying different things until you figure it out
- Be sure to utilize the rotating game camera. There are hidden things everywhere that can only be seen if you're looking at things from the right angle
- Also be sure to utilize the first person perspective with the in-game camera. There are some things hidden outside of the wide view that can only be spotted this way.
- Don't be stingy with pictures. You have a ton of album space and won't come close to running out even after doing all the in-game quests. 

Did I really love this game? Absolutely. Am I going to put it away for a while and revisit it down the road? You better believe it. Is TOEM for everyone? Probably not, but if you're a fan of this kind of fun, quirky, cute game, I highly recommend it.

Cons:

I thought Toem was cute! It gives me major Scribblenauts vibes. While their gameplay differs (photography vs. creating objects with a magical notepad), both games have you help people by collecting stars in thematically-distinct regions and seem primarily aimed at younger audiences. They also have a similar art style.

Now, apologies for what will be a spoiler-heavy review, but humor me, as Toem has left me ruminating on its color palette.

[spoiler]For almost the entire game I wished there was a bit of color. I found that the lack of color hurt the game's visual appeal and wondered if the devs just made that choice to lighten their artists' workloads a bit. However, after finally seeing toem at the end, I realized I couldn't have been more wrong. I didn't even realize right away why toem was so darned beautiful and impactful, but suddenly it dawned on me that the beautiful aurora was the first time that the player ever sees color.

This could be reading into things too much, but I took "seeing toem" as a metaphor for having a change in perspective on life. Our character travels far and wide to realize that the world we once found gray and lifeless was actually full of color. The preceding hours of seeing wholesome and beautiful things in monochrome really set up that point, so I think the color scheme choice was critical in letting the ending have the impact it did.

You start the game sitting on your bed in your room in a totally gray world looking at flowers through a TV screen. When you walk into the next room, the first thing Nana says to you is "Look who made it out of their room", as if you had been spending a lot of time in there lately, and venturing out at all was a big step for you. That's what allows for the "the day you've dreamed about", of seeing toem, to finally come; it's a return to life, or at least the start of one, brought about by literally seeing the world from a different perspective through your camera, which stands in for a shift in emotional perspective. There's a reason that Nana doesn't want you to try to experience it through her photo album; it's a lesson that is best learned yourself, and she realizes the day has come that you're ready for it.

I was curious about the meaning of toem, and an online dictionary informed me that t√∂m (i.e. toem) means "to empty" in the devs' native Swedish. You could therefore interpret "experiencing toem" as "experiencing nothingness", or leaving behind the self and having an encounter with the sublime at the top of the (likely metaphorical) mountain. This would point to having a profound and transformative emotional experience while viewing yourself from an outside perspective.[/spoiler]

Other pros:
* Lovely music. A couple of the tracks were downright special.
* Cute and wholesome. [spoiler]I love the guitar wizard :)[/spoiler]
* Decently fun gameplay loop. The photo compendium might be the closest I've been to the trick book from SSX Tricky since I was a kid.
* The game isn't voice acted, but the dialogue still gives the impression of being in Swedish, which I found interesting and fit with the setting and developers. Always fun when games unintentionally leave me thinking about linguistics.
* Some nice attention to detail, like [spoiler]setting a trend with your hat in the fashion show and encountering people around town wearing your hat afterwards.[/spoiler]
* Some cool and unexpected moments [spoiler], like the moose DJ area and the cosmic deer.[/spoiler]
* You can pet most of the animals.

Cons:
* Nearby objects looked blurry through the camera even without zooming.
* I found the menus to be a bit clunky to navigate. For example, if you access the quick select menu via the X button, you have to be holding the d-pad arrow when you let go of X to get the selected item to actually to open. It should open the second you hit the d-pad. Also, the pause menu and backpack buttons are flipped from how 99% of games set them.
* This is almost certainly a me problem, but I didn't realize until Basto that you can change the zoom level with LT and RT. For the entire base game I just tolerated the suboptimal zoom levels that would sometimes carry over from cutscenes and smaller rooms until the game would reset them on its own.

Not a very long game but very well paced. Took me a little over 4 hours to 100% the base game and every moment of it was pretty enjoyable. If you really need or want challenging games, this isn't for you, but among relaxing experience type games, this one's great.
